articles.headline: Pension Advisers Learn the Folly of Trying to Beat the Market
articles.snippet: Two advisers in Nevada have learned that investors who try to pick stocks that will outperform the market will fail to do so over long periods.
articles.abstract: Two advisers in Nevada have learned that investors who try to pick stocks that will outperform the market will fail to do so over long periods.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARSON CITY, Nev. — The Carson Nugget casino takes up the better part of a downtown block in this state capital, and a sign on the side beckons bettors with a promise of “Extremely Loose Slots.”

articles.headline: 2 American Service Members Foil Gunman in Train Attack
articles.snippet: The two men averted carnage by tackling an armed, suspected terrorist on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to France, officials said.
articles.abstract: The two men averted carnage by tackling an armed, suspected terrorist on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to France, officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The two American service members who tackled a suspected terrorist on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to Paris rushed him even though he was fully armed, then grabbed him by the neck and beat him over the head with his own automatic rifle until he was unconscious, one of them said in television interviews here on Saturday.

articles.headline: U.S. Court Reinstates Home Care Pay Rules
articles.snippet: The regulations, struck down by a lower court about nine months ago, were intended to remove an exemption in federal minimum wage and overtime laws for home care workers.
articles.abstract: The regulations, struck down by a lower court about nine months ago, were intended to remove an exemption in federal minimum wage and overtime laws for home care workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Friday reinstated regulations drawn up by the Obama administration to extend minimum wage and overtime protections to almost two million workers who provide home care for the elderly and disabled.

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton’s Woes Pushing Joe Biden to Reach Out to Those Who Could Back a Campaign
articles.snippet: Mr. Biden’s exploration of a presidential candidacy has taken on a new seriousness as he and his aides have contacted donors.
articles.abstract: Mr. Biden’s exploration of a presidential candidacy has taken on a new seriousness as he and his aides have contacted donors.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign struggles with sliding poll numbers, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s exploration of a presidential candidacy is taking on a new seriousness.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Fading Economy and Graft Crackdown Rattle China’s Leaders
articles.snippet: A slowdown could mark the end of fast growth, while a campaign against official corruption has continued longer and reached higher than most had expected.
articles.abstract: A slowdown could mark the end of fast growth, while a campaign against official corruption has continued longer and reached higher than most had expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The start to the day was hardly unusual for a senior Chinese leader in a country grappling with an economic slowdown. On the morning of July 24, Zhou Benshun attended a meeting to promote one of President Xi Jinping’s signature projects, a plan to boost growth by building a “supercity” that would integrate Beijing with the region around it.
articles.byline: By Michael Forsythe and Jonathan Ansfield

articles.headline: A Shot, a Glimpse of an AK-47, and U.S. Servicemen Pounced on Gunman on Train to France
articles.snippet: The quick action by two servicemen on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to Paris averted what officials said could have been a blood bath.
articles.abstract: The quick action by two servicemen on a high-speed train traveling from Amsterdam to Paris averted what officials said could have been a blood bath.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — It was 5:45 p.m., a normal Friday afternoon on the sleek high-speed train that takes high-level European diplomats, businesspeople, tourists and ordinary citizens between Amsterdam, Brussels and Paris.

articles.headline: Why Donald Trump Won’t Fold: Polls and People Speak
articles.snippet: Evidence suggests that the brash billionaire builder’s dominance in presidential primary polling is no mere “summer fling.”
articles.abstract: Evidence suggests that the brash billionaire builder’s dominance in presidential primary polling is no mere “summer fling.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In the command centers of Republican presidential campaigns, aides have drawn comfort from the belief that Donald J. Trump’s dominance in the polls is a political summer fling, like Herman Cain in 2011 — an unsustainable boomlet dependent on megawatt celebrity, narrow appeal and unreliable surveys of Americans with a spotty record of actually voting in primaries.
articles.byline: By Michael Barbaro, Nate Cohn and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Investors Race to Escape Risk in Once-Booming Emerging-Market Bonds
articles.snippet: A selling spree by large mutual funds has raised concerns among regulators and economists about a broader contagion if investors start to ask for their money at the same time.
articles.abstract: A selling spree by large mutual funds has raised concerns among regulators and economists about a broader contagion if investors start to ask for their money at the same time.
articles.lead_paragraph: The large mutual funds that helped fuel rapid growth in developing countries have begun hastily retreating from those investments, contributing to the recent sharp decline in global markets.

articles.headline: An Internet Mortgage Provider Reaps the Rewards of Lending Boldly
articles.snippet: Bank of Internet USA, which has extended big loans to high-earning people other lenders might shun, has been making profits, and setting off alarm bells.
articles.abstract: Bank of Internet USA, which has extended big loans to high-earning people other lenders might shun, has been making profits, and setting off alarm bells.
articles.lead_paragraph: You have substantial assets, but your income is erratic and your finances are what in polite company would be called “complex.” Your credit history may contain a smudge or two. Yet you would like to buy one more luxury apartment.

articles.headline: Ohio Bill Would Ban Abortion if Down Syndrome Is Reason
articles.snippet: Legislators are expected to approve a measure that would make it illegal for a doctor to perform an abortion on a woman terminating to avoid having a child with Down syndrome.
articles.abstract: Legislators are expected to approve a measure that would make it illegal for a doctor to perform an abortion on a woman terminating to avoid having a child with Down syndrome.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — Opening a new front in the abortion wars, abortion opponents are pushing Ohio to make it illegal for a doctor to perform an abortion if a woman is terminating her pregnancy to avoid having a baby with Down syndrome.

articles.headline: From Whitewater to Email: the Clintons’ Dogged Lawyer
articles.snippet: David E. Kendall is “one of America’s greatest lawyers,” a former adversary says, but he has drawn criticism from foes of the Clintons and concern from their friends.
articles.abstract: David E. Kendall is “one of America’s greatest lawyers,” a former adversary says, but he has drawn criticism from foes of the Clintons and concern from their friends.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — At first, he had to worry about a remote piece of land in Arkansas that no one wanted. Then there were billing records that went missing before mysteriously reappearing in the White House. And of course there was the blue dress.

articles.headline: Much at Stake in Academy’s Hunt for a 2016 Oscars Producer
articles.snippet: Previous awards shows have seen a decline in ratings, so the pressure is on for officers and executives of the Academy as they select overseers of the next Oscars broadcast.
articles.abstract: Previous awards shows have seen a decline in ratings, so the pressure is on for officers and executives of the Academy as they select overseers of the next Oscars broadcast.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Will the next Academy Awards ceremony be street smart, like the “House Party” movies? Digitally savvy, with a BuzzFeed twist? Or as grandly mainstream as, oh, almost anything Tom Hanks has ever done?

articles.headline: The ‘Unicorn’ Club, Now Admitting New Members
articles.snippet: Over 100 start-ups have crossed the billion-dollar valuation threshold, and an analysis from CB Insights showed 50 more are poised to reach this benchmark.
articles.abstract: Over 100 start-ups have crossed the billion-dollar valuation threshold, and an analysis from CB Insights showed 50 more are poised to reach this benchmark.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One hallmark of the current technology boom is a generation of start-ups valued at $1 billion or more by investors. Now meet the start-ups-in-waiting that may be next to reach that mark, if the white-hot market continues.

articles.headline: 50 Companies That May Be the Next Start-Up Unicorns
articles.snippet: Which start-ups may be next to ascend to the $1 billion valuation club? Here’s a list of 50, as compiled through an analysis from the research firm CB Insights.
articles.abstract: Which start-ups may be next to ascend to the $1 billion valuation club? Here’s a list of 50, as compiled through an analysis from the research firm CB Insights.
articles.lead_paragraph: It used to be a rare thing when start-ups were valued at $1 billion or more by their investors. Now it’s become so common that there are at least 131 start-ups boasting such valuations and a term — “unicorns” — to refer to the companies.

articles.headline: Big Investors Are Finding Ripe Start-Up Targets in Europe
articles.snippet: Venture capital, private equity and other big investors are increasingly finding technology start-up investment targets in Europe.
articles.abstract: Venture capital, private equity and other big investors are increasingly finding technology start-up investment targets in Europe.
articles.lead_paragraph: Klaus Hommels has invested in some of Europe’s most successful start-ups. That includes Spotify, the music-streaming service, and Klarna, a Swedish online payments company valued at more than $2 billion. He has also backed several American tech giants like Facebook and Airbnb, the vacation-rental site.

articles.headline: Europe Facing New Uncertainty in Terrorism Fight
articles.snippet: The sheer number of militant suspects combined with a widening field of potential targets have presented European officials with what they concede is a nearly insurmountable surveillance task.
articles.abstract: The sheer number of militant suspects combined with a widening field of potential targets have presented European officials with what they concede is a nearly insurmountable surveillance task.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Two days after a young Moroccan man was thwarted from an apparent plan to cause carnage on a Paris-bound express train, European officials confronted the deepening quandary of what additional steps they could take in the face of such attacks on soft targets, short of paralyzing public spaces or even more intrusive surveillance.

articles.headline: Sillerman’s Failed Bid, Debts and Growing Losses Test SFX Investors’ Patience
articles.snippet: Despite strong returns for its rivals, the company has seen debts mount and its stock collapse after a failed takeover bid by Robert F. X. Sillerman.
articles.abstract: Despite strong returns for its rivals, the company has seen debts mount and its stock collapse after a failed takeover bid by Robert F. X. Sillerman.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert F. X. Sillerman didn’t start the dance-music festival promoter SFX Entertainment out of a love for the music. Instead, he acted with cold logical reasoning backed by demographic marketing.

articles.headline: A Sprawl of Ghost Homes in Aging Tokyo Suburbs
articles.snippet: Some eight million unoccupied homes across Japan are the most visible sign of human retreat in a country where the population is forecast to fall by a third over the next 50 years.
articles.abstract: Some eight million unoccupied homes across Japan are the most visible sign of human retreat in a country where the population is forecast to fall by a third over the next 50 years.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOKOSUKA, Japan — Ever since her elderly neighbor moved a decade ago, Yoriko Haneda has done what she can to keep the empty house she left behind from becoming an eyesore. Ms. Haneda regularly trims its shrubs and clips its narrow strip of grass, maintaining its perfect view of the sea.

articles.headline: Future Risks of an Iran Nuclear Deal
articles.snippet: Even some of its strongest backers say they fear that President Obama has oversold some of the deal’s virtues in blocking paths to a nuclear weapon.
articles.abstract: Even some of its strongest backers say they fear that President Obama has oversold some of the deal’s virtues in blocking paths to a nuclear weapon.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Obama begins his three-week push to win approval of the Iran nuclear deal, he is confronting this political reality: His strongest argument in favor of passage has also become his greatest vulnerability.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Michael R. Gordon

articles.headline: Rolling Stone Moves Beyond the Fray
articles.snippet: As the magazine works to repair its journalistic reputation, its founder, Jann Wenner, is gradually handing the reins to his son.
articles.abstract: As the magazine works to repair its journalistic reputation, its founder, Jann Wenner, is gradually handing the reins to his son.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gus Wenner is 25, not much older than his father, Jann S. Wenner, was when he started Rolling Stone in 1967.

articles.headline: As Minimum Wages Rise, Restaurants Say No to Tips, Yes to Higher Prices
articles.snippet: A no-tipping policy has already been adopted by a small number of restaurants, with others taking a wait-and-see attitude.
articles.abstract: A no-tipping policy has already been adopted by a small number of restaurants, with others taking a wait-and-see attitude.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Restaurant owners, customers and staff have long railed against the tyranny of tipping, but like a love affair gone bad, it has proved difficult to quit.

articles.headline: A Plunge in China Rattles Markets Across the Globe
articles.snippet: The global market turmoil spread across Asia, Europe and the United States, with the benchmark Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index falling nearly 4 percent.
articles.abstract: The global market turmoil spread across Asia, Europe and the United States, with the benchmark Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index falling nearly 4 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks around the world tumbled in volatile trading on Monday, leaving investors to wonder how much government officials can and will do to insulate the global economy from the turmoil.
articles.byline: By Nathaniel Popper and Neil Gough

articles.headline: Intel to Invest Heavily in Software That Enhances Cloud-Computing Capabilities
articles.snippet: An expected $100 million in funding to be directed to cloud-computing software and a related start-up reflects the company’s view of its own future.
articles.abstract: An expected $100 million in funding to be directed to cloud-computing software and a related start-up reflects the company’s view of its own future.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Intel, the world’s biggest maker of computer chips, has seen its future. There may not be room for some of Intel’s old friends in it.
